@SmarterEveryDay This is incorrect: "In general, you want your measurement device to be one order of magnitude faster than the event being measured."  The Nyquist Frequency is twice the frequency being sampled, not an order of magnitude.
that's the same practice of using a timing gun to set engine timing

@SmarterEveryDay This is one of my favourite demonstrations of this principle! However, in general you want a sampling rate that is just a little bit higher than twice the maximum frequency that you want to sample. This is called the Nyquist theorem. If you know for certain that there are higher frequencies present in the thing being measured, and you have no way of constructing an anti-alias filter, then an order of magnitude higher sampling rate might be a good idea (like a safety margin).

The original technique for observing high speed signals with an oscilloscope used this technique in what was called a "sampling Scope". It could show GHz signals with a sub GHz scope bandwidth.  It obviously only worked with repettitive signals.

No, that's different. In digital imaging of any kind - primarily animation and gaming - anti-aliasing refers to sub-pixel detail that smooths out edges. Imagine a profile view of a stairway - that's the whole pixels, without anti-aliasing. It's fast to render, but looks chunky. Anti-aliasing basically puts a ramp down the stairs, so there's less evident pixel-chunkery, and a smoother look.
